questions.text: The vessel carrying oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus is:
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Umbilical vein

Explanation

Fetal Circulation

All Options: 

  • Option A: Umbilical vein: This carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus
  • Option B: Umbilical artery: This carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta
  • Option C: Ductus venosus: This shunts blood from the umbilical vein to the IVC
  • Option D: Ductus arteriosus: This shunts blood from the pulmonary artery to the aorta

 

Educational Objective: 

  • Oxygenated blood enters the fetus through: Umbilical Vein
    • Functional closure: Occurs after closure of umbilical artery
    • Forms the ligamentum teres 
  • Deoxygenated Blood exits the fetus through Umbilical arteries
    • Functional closure of umbilical arteries: immediately after birth
    • Anatomical closure: 2 – 3months
    • Proximal part form the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal part form the lateral umbilical ligaments
  • Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from umbilical vein to IVC
    • Functional closure 10 – 96h after birth
    • Anatomic closure: 3 -7 days
    • Forms the ligamentum venosum
  • Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from Pulmonary artery to Aorta
    • Functional closure: 12 – 24 h
    • Anatomic closure: 2 – 3 weeks
  • Foramen ovale
    • Functional closure soon after birth
    • Anatomical closure at 1 year

 

 

Ref: Page no 129, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: It does not cross the placenta
Trophoblast receptor-mediated transfer
Facilitated diffusion involving calcium binding protein

questions.text: How does Immunoglobulin G (IgG) cross the placenta?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Trophoblast receptor-mediated transfer

Explanation

Placental Transfer

  • Most substances with a molecular mass < 500Da pass readily through placental tissue by simple diffusion
  • These include CO2, water, most electrolytes and anesthetic gases
  • Insulin, steroid hormones and thyroid hormones cross the placenta but very slowly
  • Hormones synthesized in the syncytiotrophoblasts (hCG and hPL) enter both maternal and fetal circulation but concentration is higher in maternal circulation
  • High molecular weight substances do not traverse the placenta EXCEPT IgG (molecular weight is 160,000) – This is transferred by a specific trophoblastic receptor mediated mechanism
  • IgG is the only immunoglobulin to cross the placenta

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Placental Transfer

  • Most substances with a molecular mass < 500Da pass readily through placental tissue by simple diffusion
  • These include CO2, water, most electrolytes and anesthetic gases
  • Insulin, steroid hormones and thyroid hormones cross the placenta but very slowly
  • Hormones synthesized in the syncytiotrophoblasts (hCG and hPL) enter both maternal and fetal circulation but concentration is higher in maternal circulation
  • High molecular weight substances do not traverse the placenta EXCEPT IgG (molecular weight is 160,000) – This is transferred by a specific trophoblastic receptor mediated mechanism
  • IgG is the only immunoglobulin to cross the placenta

 

Ref: Page no 140, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: What is the uteroplacental blood flow at term?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. 700-900 mL/min

Explanation:

  • Maternal blood within the intervillous space is the primary source of maternal–fetal transfer.
  • Blood from the maternal spiral arteries directly bathes the trophoblast layer that surrounds the villi.
  • Substances transferred from mother to fetus first enter the intervillous space and are then transported to the syncytiotrophoblasts
  • Intervillous and uteroplacental blood flow increases throughout pregnancy
  • At term, uteroplacental blood flow near term ranges from 700 to 900 mL/min, and most of this blood apparently goes to the intervillous space

 

Educational Objective: 

  • Maternal blood within the intervillous space is the primary source of maternal–fetal transfer.
  • Blood from the maternal spiral arteries directly bathes the trophoblast layer that surrounds the villi.
  • Substances transferred from mother to fetus first enter the intervillous space and are then transported to the syncytiotrophoblasts
  • Intervillous and uteroplacental blood flow increases throughout pregnancy
  • At term, uteroplacental blood flow near term ranges from 700 to 900 mL/min, and most of this blood apparently goes to the intervillous space

 

Ref: Page no 370, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: It is produced exclusively by the placenta
Concentrations peak in amniotic fluid at term
95% of placental production enters the fetal circulation
Abnormal levels have been associated with FGR

questions.text: Which of the following statements about leptin is true?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Abnormal levels have been associated with FGR

Explanation

  • Leptin is a polypeptide hormone which was originally identified as a product of adipocytes and a regulator of energy homeostasis by curbing appetite.
  • It also contributes to angiogenesis, hemopoiesis, osteogenesis, pulmonary maturation, and neuroendocrine, immune, and reproductive functions
  • Leptin is produced by the mother, fetus, and placenta.
  • It is expressed in syncytiotrophoblasts and fetal vascular endothelial cells.
  • Of placental production, 5% enters the fetal circulation & 95 percent is transferred to the mother.
  • Leptin concentrations peak in amnionic fluid at mid-pregnancy
  • Fetal serum leptin levels begin increasing at approximately 34 weeks and are correlated with fetal weight.
  • This hormone is involved in the development and maturation of the heart, brain, kidneys, and pancreas, and its levels are decreased with fetal-growth restriction.
  • Abnormal levels are also associated with fetal-growth disorders, gestational diabetes, and preeclampsia, but not maternal obesity

 

Educational Objective: 

  • Leptin is a polypeptide hormone which was originally identified as a product of adipocytes and a regulator of energy homeostasis by curbing appetite.
  • It also contributes to angiogenesis, hemopoiesis, osteogenesis, pulmonary maturation, and neuroendocrine, immune, and reproductive functions
  • Leptin is produced by the mother, fetus, and placenta.
  • It is expressed in syncytiotrophoblasts and fetal vascular endothelial cells.
  • Of placental production, 5% enters the fetal circulation & 95 percent is transferred to the mother.
  • Leptin concentrations peak in amnionic fluid at mid-pregnancy
  • Fetal serum leptin levels begin increasing at approximately 34 weeks and are correlated with fetal weight.
  • This hormone is involved in the development and maturation of the heart, brain, kidneys, and pancreas, and its levels are decreased with fetal-growth restriction.
  • Abnormal levels are also associated with fetal-growth disorders, gestational diabetes, and preeclampsia, but not maternal obesity

Ref: Page 364, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks
By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid
After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life
Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following statements of the fetal thyroid gland is true?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid

Explanation

Let us discuss all the options

  • Option A: The fetal thyroid starts to make hormones starting at 36 weeks: This is incorrect; the feta thyroid starts secreting hormones at 1- - 12 weeks
  • Option B: By 12 weeks, the fetal thyroid is concentrating iodide more avidly than the maternal thyroid: Ths is correct. The placenta actively concentrates iodine on the fetal side, and by 12 weeks and throughout pregnancy, the fetal thyroid concentrates iodine more avidly than does the maternal thyroid.
  • Option C: After birth, cooling to room temperature causes a sudden and marked decrease in secretion of TSH which results in low serum T4 with a nadir at 24-36h of life: This is incorrect. Immediately after birth, thyroid function and metabolism undergo major change. Cooling to room temperature evokes a sudden and marked increase in TSH secretion. This in turn causes a progressive increase in serum T4 levels that are maximal 24 to 36 hours after birth.
  • Option D: Maternal and fetal levels of TBG decrease throughout pregnancy. This is incorrect. Normal fetal levels of free thyroxine (T4), free triiodothyronine (T3), and TBG rise steadily throughout gestation

 

Educational Objective: 

  • By 10 to 12 weeks, the thyroid gland can synthesize hormones
  • The placenta actively concentrates iodine on the fetal side, and by 12 weeks and throughout pregnancy, the fetal thyroid concentrates iodine more avidly than does the maternal thyroid.
  • Normal fetal levels of free thyroxine (T4), free triiodothyronine (T3), and TBG rise steadily throughout gestation
  • Fetal thyroid hormone plays a role in the normal development of virtually all fetal tissues, especially the brain
  • Immediately after birth, thyroid function and metabolism undergo major change. Cooling to room temperature evokes a sudden and marked increase in TSH secretion. This in turn causes a progressive increase in serum T4 levels that are maximal 24 to 36 hours after birth.

 

 

Ref: Page 359, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Fetal growth restriction
Maternal administered frusemide

questions.text: Which of the following will increase fetal urine production?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Maternal administered frusemide

Explanation

  • The fetal kidneys start producing urine at 12 weeks.
  • By 18 weeks, they are producing 7 to 14 mL/d, and at term, this increases to 650 mL/d
  • Urine production is increased with
    • Diabetes mellitus (fetal hyperglycemia)
    • Increase blood flow to the fetus (like in recipient twin in TTTS)
    • Maternally administered furosemide
  • Urine production is decreased in
    • Utero placental insufficiency (Option C)
    • Fetal-growth restriction (Option B)
    • Obstruction of the urethra, bladder, ureters, or renal pelvis (Option A)

 

Educational Objective:

  • The fetal kidneys start producing urine at 12 weeks.
  • By 18 weeks, they are producing 7 to 14 mL/d, and at term, this increases to 650 mL/d
  • Urine production is increased with
    • Diabetes mellitus (fetal hyperglycemia)
    • Increase blood flow to the fetus (like in recipient twin in TTTS)
    • Maternally administered furosemide
  • Urine production is decreased in
    • Utero placental insufficiency 
    • Fetal-growth restriction 
    • Obstruction of the urethra, bladder, ureters, or renal pelvis

 

Ref: Page no 358, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Which of the following gives meconium its greenish-black color?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Biliverdin

Explanation

  • Fetal bowel contents consist of various products of secretion, such as glycerophospholipids from the lung, desquamated fetal cells, lanugo, scalp hair, and vernix.
  • It also contains undigested debris from swallowed amnionic fluid.
  • The dark greenish-black color forms from bile pigments, especially biliverdin.
  • Meconium can pass from normal bowel peristalsis in the mature fetus or from vagal stimulation.
  • It can also pass when hypoxia stimulates arginine vasopressin (AVP) release from the fetal pituitary gland. AVP stimulates colonic smooth muscle to contract, resulting in intra-amnionic defecation
  • Meconium is toxic to the respiratory system, and its inhalation can result in meconium aspiration syndrome.

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Fetal bowel contents consist of various products of secretion, such as glycerophospholipids from the lung, desquamated fetal cells, lanugo, scalp hair, and vernix.
  • It also contains undigested debris from swallowed amnionic fluid.
  • The dark greenish-black color forms from bile pigments, especially biliverdin.
  • Meconium can pass from normal bowel peristalsis in the mature fetus or from vagal stimulation.
  • It can also pass when hypoxia stimulates arginine vasopressin (AVP) release from the fetal pituitary gland. AVP stimulates colonic smooth muscle to contract, resulting in intra-amnionic defecation
  • Meconium is toxic to the respiratory system, and its inhalation can result in meconium aspiration syndrome.

 

 

Ref: Page no 355, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: At what gestational age does swallowing begin?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 10-12 weeks

Explanation

  • Swallowing begins at 10 to 12 weeks, coincident with the ability of the small intestine to undergo peristalsis and to actively transport glucose

 

Educational Objective: 

Swallowing begins at 10 to 12 weeks, coincident with the ability of the small intestine to undergo peristalsis and to actively transport glucose

 

Ref: Page 354, Williams Obstetric 26th edition

questions.text: Where does the biosynthesis of surfactant take place?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Type 2 pneumocytes

Explanation

  • Biosynthesis of surfactant takes place in the type II pneumocytes.
  • Phospholipid is the primary surface tension–lowering component of surfactant, whereas the apoproteins aid the forming and reforming of a surface film.
  • The major apoprotein is surfactant A (SP-A), which is a glycoprotein with a molecular weight of 28,000 to 35,000 Da. It is synthesized in the type II cells, and its content in amnionic fluid increases with gestational age and fetal lung maturity
  • Antenatal betamethasone and dexamethasone increase surfactant production when administered antenatally (given in women expected to deliver preterm) and are given for antenatal lung maturation.

 

Educational Objective: 

  • Biosynthesis of surfactant takes place in the type II pneumocytes.
  • Phospholipid is the primary surface tension–lowering component of surfactant, whereas the apoproteins aid the forming and reforming of a surface film.
  • The major apoprotein is surfactant A (SP-A), which is a glycoprotein with a molecular weight of 28,000 to 35,000 Da. It is synthesized in the type II cells, and its content in amnionic fluid increases with gestational age and fetal lung maturity
  • Antenatal betamethasone and dexamethasone increase surfactant production when administered antenatally (given in women expected to deliver preterm) and are given for antenatal lung maturation.

Ref: Page 353, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Approximately what percentage of the total hemoglobin is hemoglobin F in a term fetus?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. 75%

Explanation

  • Hb is composed of two copies of two different peptide chains, which determine the type of hemoglobin produced
  • Hemoglobin types transition throughout pregnancy.
    • Alpha (α) and zeta (ζ) globin chains are interchangeable.
    • The beta (β) globin chain can be replaced by epsilon (ε), gamma (γ), or delta ( δ) globin chains.
    • In embryonic life (stage I), ζ and ε globin chains exist
    • In fetal life (stage 2):  Hemoglobin F is the main type (α and γ globin chains)
    • After birth (stage III), HbA1 predominates (α and β chains)
  • The amount of hemoglobin F in fetal erythrocytes begins to decrease in the last weeks of pregnancy.
  • At term, approximately three fourths (75%) of total hemoglobin levels are hemoglobin F.
  • During the first 6 to 12 months of life, the hemoglobin F proportion continues to decline and eventually reaches the low levels found in adult erythrocytes

 

Educational Objective:

  • Hemoglobin types transition throughout pregnancy.
    • Alpha (α) and zeta (ζ) globin chains are interchangeable.
    • The beta (β) globin chain can be replaced by epsilon (ε), gamma (γ), or delta ( δ) globin chains.
    • In embryonic life (stage I), ζ and ε globin chains exist
    • In fetal life (stage 2):  Hemoglobin F is the main type (α and γ globin chains)
    • After birth (stage III), HbA1 predominates (α and β chains)

 

Ref: Page 353, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: After birth, the intra-abdominal remnants of the umbilical vein become which of the following?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Ligamentum teres

All Options:

  • Option A: Ligamentum teres: This is the remnant of the umbilical vein
  • Option B: Ligamentum venosum: This is the remnant of the ductus venosus
  • Option C: Ligamentum vascularum: There is no such term
  • Option D: Umbilical ligaments: This is the remnant of the umbilical arteries

 

Educational Objective:

  • Oxygenated blood enters the fetus through: Umbilical Vein
    • Functional closure: Occurs after closure of umbilical artery
    • Forms the ligamentum teres 
  • Deoxygenated Blood exits the fetus through Umbilical arteries
    • Functional closure of umbilical arteries: immediately after birth
    • Anatomical closure: 2 – 3 months
    • Proximal part form the superior vesical arteries
    • Distal part form the lateral umbilical ligaments
  • Ductus venosus: Shunts blood from umbilical vein to IVC
    • Functional closure 10 – 96h after birth
    • Anatomic closure: 3 -7 days
    • Forms the ligamentum venosum
  • Ductus arteriosus: Shunts blood from Pulmonary artery to Aorta
    • Functional closure: 12 – 24 h
    • Anatomic closure: 2 – 3 weeks
  • Foramen ovale
    • Functional closure soon after birth
    • Anatomical closure at 1 year

 

 

Ref: Page no 343, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Varies depending on gestational age

questions.text: How does the oxygen content coming to the fetal heart from the inferior vena cava compare to the oxygen content of the blood leaving the placenta?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Lower

Explanation

Fetal Circulation

 

 

Educational Objective:

  • The oxygen content coming to the fetal heart from the inferior vena cava is lower than the oxygen content of the blood leaving the placenta

Ref: Page no 343, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Fetal sleep cycle

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 39 weeks' gestation presents with prolonged and severe uterine contractions and reduced variability in the fetal heart rate tracing. The baseline fetal heart rate is normal. What is the most likely cause of this fetal heart rate pattern?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fetal distress

 

Explanation:

 

  • A pattern of prolonged and severe uterine contractions, along with reduced variability in the fetal heart rate tracing, is concerning for fetal distress. Reduced variability can be a sign of fetal compromise, and further evaluation is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Fetal sleep cycle: This will present with absent accelerations (Reactivity) on the fetal heart rate tracing. Baseline and variability is usually normal
  • Uterine contractions: A fetus who is not hypoxic will tolerate uterine contractions
  • Maternal dehydration: This usually presents as fetal tachycardia

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reduced variability is seen in:

 

  • Fetal hypoxia/ acidosis
  • Fetal CNS depression
  • Drugs in pregnancy

 

 

Ref: Page No 462, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Immediate induction of labor
Biophysical profile (BPP) assessment
Continue routine prenatal care

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 39 weeks' gestation presents for a routine antenatal checkup. The clinician performs a non-stress test (NST), which shows the absence of accelerations in the fetal heart rate tracing. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Biophysical profile (BPP) assessment

 

Explanation:

 

  • In the absence of accelerations on a non-stress test (NST), ideally the NST should be extended till another 20 mins.
  • If there are still no accelerations, a biophysical profile (BPP) assessment is the next best step to evaluate fetal well-being more comprehensively.
  • The BPP includes additional parameters on USG (fetal breathing movements, fetal tone, fetal movements, and amniotic fluid volume)
  • The BPP gives a score (Manning score) and based on this score, further management is advised

 

Other options

 

  • The decision for delivery (induction of labor/ cesarean) cannot be taken on a non-reactive NST as there is a high false positive rate with an NST
  • Continue routine prenatal care: If the NST is non-reactive, a BPP should be offered and confirmed that the fetus is doing ok.

 

Educational Objective

 

  • An NST is usually the 1st test done for antepartum fetal monitoring
  • A non-reactive NST warrants further checking by a Biophysical Profile

 

 

Ref: Page No336, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman with gestational diabetes is scheduled for an elective cesarean section at 39 weeks' gestation. During the procedure, the infant appears lethargic and is not feeding well. What is the most likely cause of the infant's condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoglycemia

 

Explanation:

 

  • Infants born to mothers with gestational diabetes are at risk of hypoglycemia due to the abrupt cessation of the continuous glucose supply from the mother. This is called as Pederson Hypothesis
  • Hypoglycemia can lead to lethargy and respiratory distress in the newborn.
  • Pederson Hypothesis as shown below describes the complications in a neonate of a diabetic mother

 

 

Other Options

 

  • Option B: Neonatal hyperbilirubinemia, which is seen in infants of diabetic mothers, will present as icterus
  • Option C: Hypocalcemia is seen in infants of diabetic mothers
  • Option D: Meconium aspiration presents as respiratory distress

 

Educational Objective: Neonatal complications of a diabetic mother can be attributed to Pederson Hypothesis which is shown in the image below

 

 

 

Ref: Page No 1102 , William’s Obstetrics 25th edition
